image.altText: A woman nurses a child in a chair.

props.synopsis: Over the past decade the number of people accessing donor sperms to start a family solo has risen 50 per cent at Australia's largest fertility clinic, despite a national sperm shortage, waitlists and major financial costs.

title.children: Jabet is a single parent by choice. The number of people choosing to do the same is growing

image.altText: A fijian woman with long bonde hair smiles outside on a sunny day holding a coffee

props.synopsis: When Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka took power last year, many celebrated, hoping it signified a new dawn for the country. So, has Fiji changed for the better?

title.children: 'Shoot the dogs': Shania celebrated a new Fiji, but one year on a decision left her 'shocked'

image.altText: CCUTENDTRMIBETAELIDSAW these are the red tin letters that need solving.

props.synopsis: For more than a decade, the Tweed Regional Museum in northern New South Wales tried to solve a red-letter anagram. Here's how they finally cracked it.

title.children: Jumbled red-letter riddle takes 13 years to solve

image.altText: The battered body of Janelle Patton was found at a grassy reserve

props.synopsis: In 2002, the first murder on Norfolk Island in more than 150 years confused police, shocked the small island community and made global headlines. The killer approaching the end of his sentence.

title.children: Norfolk Island was rocked by this brutal murder. The killer will soon be released

image.altText: Luara Lynch playing upright bass

props.synopsis: Members of the Chicks — who dropped "Dixie" from the band name in 2020 amid civil rights protests in the US — say they are "shocked and saddened" by the news.

title.children: Founding member of the Dixie Chicks dies aged 65

image.altText: Joe Biden sits in front of Israeli and American flags. He is speaking.

props.synopsis: The White House's war talk has evolved as the world's sympathies have been shifting from Israel to Gaza. But America's words are proving to mean little without action, writes Brad Ryan in Washington DC.

title.children: The gap between Biden's words and deeds on Gaza is growing — and there are two words he can't shake

image.altText: Elon Musk on stage holding a microphone.

props.synopsis: Twitter's lawyers argue that when the company said it would pay employees 50 per cent of their 2022 target bonuses, it made only an oral promise that was not a contract.

title.children: Twitter violated contract by failing to pay millions in bonuses, US judge rules

image.altText: An advertisement for Woolworths mince pies that feature a star shape on the top.

props.synopsis: Woolworths has recalled shortcrust mince pies right before Christmas in NSW because of potential metal contamination.

title.children: Mince pies recalled by Woolworths due to possible metal contamination

image.altText: Piano caked in brown mud, with sheet music still sitting on the lid.

props.synopsis: From heroic helicopter and tinny rescues to shocking damage and crocodiles in town, the Far North Queensland flood disaster shows life there at its best and worst.

title.children: This remote pub has survived 148 years, but floods have thrown it a new challenge

image.altText: A hand holds a bunch of cherries that are split down the side due to rain.

props.synopsis: Farming can be tough and normally the sound of rain is welcome, but for Tasmanian cherry farmers Gene and Laura, recent downpours had them "swearing and cursing", knowing their crop was unlikely to survive.

title.children: Heartbreak for family farmers as rain devastates cherry crop ahead of season peak

image.altText: Joe Parker holds up his hand

props.synopsis: Anthony Joshua delivers a statement performance to win his third fight of the year, Jai Opetaia dominates with a round-one knockout, and Joseph Parker demolishes Deontay Wilder in the upset of the night at the Day of Reckoning in Saudi Arabia.

title.children: New Zealand's Joseph Parker stuns Deontay Wilder, Anthony Joshua, Jai Opetaia win by stoppage

image.altText: Theoutside of the NAAJA building in Darwin.

props.synopsis: Australia's biggest Indigenous legal service declares it is back on a path to being able to provide strong representation for vulnerable clients.

title.children: Australia's biggest Indigenous legal agency says its governance problems are over, but some don't agree

image.altText: Eva Lawler and Chansey Paech smile during a press conference.

props.synopsis: New Chief Minister Eva Lawler says the Labor caucus "unanimously" decided that she should lead the party. But the spectacle of a leadership race, right before Christmas, is another hit to the party's ambitions to win a third term.

title.children: Territory Labor narrowly avoided a nightmare before Christmas, but its biggest challenge lies ahead

image.altText: a woman holds her baby after a sc section with her husband in a gown holding his other baby

props.synopsis: Kelsey Hatcher gives birth to two babies on separate days in what her obstetrician describes as "a true medical surprise".

title.children: Alabama woman with two wombs gives birth to two girls on separate days

image.altText: A woman with short grey hair sitting down and smiling next to her black dog.

props.synopsis: Many people’s concerns about COVID have reduced significantly this Christmas compared to previous festive periods. But for some people, COVID precautions are still front of mind ahead of family gatherings.

title.children: For some, keeping safe from COVID-19 this Christmas is just as important as it was last year

image.altText: Yekaterina Duntsova stands in front of a Russian flag, she is wearing a blaser and has a shoulder-length bob

props.synopsis: Former TV journalist Yekaterina Duntsova is barred from running against President Vladimir Putin in an election next March because of alleged mistakes in her application to register as a candidate.

title.children: Would-be challenger Duntsova barred from running against Putin in Russian election

image.altText: Artwork containing Australian and American rugby league player

props.synopsis: When Australia met the USA in Philadelphia one cold night in 2004, it was supposed to be a smash-up but after 40 minutes the Tomahawks were on the verge of one of the biggest boilovers in sporting history.

title.children: One night in Philly — how the USA Tomahawks nearly pulled off the greatest upset in rugby league history

image.altText: Three lifesavers lined up watching over a busy beach at Ocean Grove.

props.synopsis: Life Saving Victoria says cyber hackers accessed one of its servers in late November. It says the personal information accessed was limited.

title.children: Life Saving Victoria targeted by cyber hackers

image.altText: A player picks up weeds in a bush setting.

props.synopsis: Western Force coach Simon Cron believes his side is on the cusp of big things, and as part of the team's preseason training players spent five days clearing firebreaks for a community devastated by bushfires in 2021.

title.children: Western Force players endure a different kind of preseason as they eye off 2024 Super Rugby finals

image.altText: Hipster woman listens to earphones on busy street

props.synopsis: Does a serving of science or some fascinating facts get your synapses firing? Are you feeling some serious holiday podcast bingeing coming on? Well, look no further.

title.children: Giant squid, anaesthesia and pet slime: Podcasts for fans of science and nature

image.altText: A record cover with the word GOANNA and a red and yellow image of Uluru is held in someone's hand.

props.synopsis: The digital age may have removed the "tactile experience" of looking at an album cover, but memorable music art lives on, assisted by Australia's vinyl revival.

title.children: Why album cover art is still important in the age of music streaming

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt and hat sits on a toilet, fully-clothed

props.synopsis: A waterless loo that keeps the flies away could offer a healthy solution for a tricky problem in the Australian outback.

title.children: A new kind of outback toilet gets a dry run, with 'huge possibilities' for remote tourism

image.altText: A woman holds a little black puppy

props.synopsis: There's no such thing as the perfect dog, says breeder Jody Hafey. But that doesn't stop her clocking up the air miles to find the next best thing.

title.children: Why Jody had to go to Europe on a quest for the 'perfect dog'

image.altText: Two young teenage girls sit at a table and smile shyly at the camera in school uniform.

props.synopsis: Beyond the crisis centres and police check-ups, work to teach children behaviour to help prevent family and domestic violence is underway in schools, and service providers say there is room to expand.

title.children: Fight to break family, domestic violence cycle taken into classrooms via respectful relationship programs

image.altText: Four women standing in front of plant and a building with their arms around each other

props.synopsis: These four mothers share a special bond, over one of the most traumatic experiences a parent could endure. They're calling on anyone who can to donate blood because it could save children like theirs.

title.children: A mother's plea: Donate blood this Christmas and save a life

image.altText: Tao Zhangin a brown hat and orange jacket

props.synopsis: The national charity said between 15 to 20 per cent of calls have been in relation to cost of living concerns, a statistic Lifeline hasn't seen since the peak of the pandemic.

title.children: 'Historically high levels': Lifeline sees spike in calls as Australians struggle with financial distress

image.altText: Aerial of flooding in Cairns

props.synopsis: Some flood victims are living in limbo, facing weeks and months of displacement. The Cairns rental crisis means there are no homes available to accommodate those in unlivable housing, while local leaders urge Airbnb hosts to step up.

title.children: The Cairns rental crisis means flood victims consider leaving town for Christmas

image.altText: A person knealing in front of a pile of candles and flowers.

props.synopsis: Bells rang across Czechia on Saturday and flags flew at half mast as the country mourned victims of the its worst mass shooting that killed 14 at a Prague university on Thursday.

title.children: Czechs remember victims of university mass shooting as country observes national day of mourning

image.altText: A child smiles in her new lounge room

props.synopsis: Emma and Dallas had feared that they and their nine children would be spending Christmas Day in the bush, but this week they received the best news they could have hoped for — a house they can call home for the next 18 months.

title.children: Homeless Bendigo family grateful for Christmas present: moving from a tent to a house

image.altText: Beth Mooney

props.synopsis: Tahlia McGrath stars again, scoring 73 to raise Australia's hopes in the Mumbai Test, but India remain in the box seat with a day to play.

title.children: Australia lead by 46 runs but India well placed in women's Test

image.altText: Collage of a dog injured next to three identical Facebook posts.

props.synopsis: Injured animals are increasingly being used as a new tactic to trick Australians out of their cash, data or both on Facebook.

title.children: Jenny was left for dead in Ohio. Now she's a pawn for Facebook fraudsters

image.altText: NomanAli

props.synopsis: Pakistan loses Noman Ali for the rest of the Test series against Australia after he was rushed to hospital for appendicitis surgery.

title.children: Spinner rushed to hospital for surgery ahead of Boxing Day Test in another blow for Pakistan's bowling stocks

image.altText: A yellow tarp full of opened abalone, small crabs, flippers and fishing gear

props.synopsis: Eight alleged poachers have been caught in possession of more than 150 abalone and crabs in South Australia's Yorke Peninsula, police have said.

title.children: Commercial quantity of abalone seized from alleged poachers on South Australian beach

image.altText: A man climbing up a post to pull out a stop sign

props.synopsis: A man with bolt cutters removes a stop sign emblazoned with the images of three military drones.

title.children: Banksy artwork taken from London street less than an hour after it was revealed

image.altText: two men in christmas outfits in snow

props.synopsis: The 80s Christmas hit beats out Mariah Carey and Sam Ryder in a tight competition.

title.children: 'George would be beside himself': Wham! celebrates reaching UK Christmas number one after 39 years
